Lebesgue Measure Construction

Posted on 2020-10-07 Edited on 2024-03-12

Measure Space

Let Ω\OmegaΩ be a set and 2Ω2^\Omega2Ω be the power set of Ω\OmegaΩ.

σ\sigmaσ-Algebra

Definition. A collection of subsets F⊆2Ω\mathcal{F} \subseteq 2^\OmegaF⊆2Ω is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra (or σ\sigmaσ-field) if

  • It is closed under countable union, intersection and complement.

Measure

Definition. Given a collection of subsets F⊆2Ω\mathcal{F} \subseteq 2^\OmegaF⊆2Ω, a function μ:F→R\mu : \mathcal{F} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}μ:F→R is a measure if it satisfies

  1. It is non-negative: ∀A∈F,μ(A)≥0\forall A \in \mathcal{F}, \mu(A) \ge 0∀A∈F,μ(A)≥0.

  2. The empty set is mapped to 0: μ(∅)=0\mu(\emptyset) = 0μ(∅)=0.

  3. σ\sigmaσ-additivity: if Ai∈FA_i \in \mathcal{F}Ai​∈F is a countable sequence of disjoint sets, s.t., ∪i≥1Ai∈F\cup_{i \ge 1} A_i \in \mathcal{F}∪i≥1​Ai​∈F, then

μ(∪i≥1Ai)=∑i≥1μ(Ai). \mu(\cup_{i \ge 1} A_i) = \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu(A_i ). μ(∪i≥1​Ai​)=i≥1∑​μ(Ai​).

Measure Space

Definition. A measure space (Ω,F,μ)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mu)(Ω,F,μ) consists of three part:

  1. A set Ω\OmegaΩ, on which it is defined;

  2. A σ\sigmaσ-field F\mathcal{F}F that contains all measurable sets;

  3. A measure μ\muμ defined on F\mathcal{F}F.

In general, it is not easy to construct a measure space on Ω\OmegaΩ directly. Our indirect construction consists of three steps:

  1. Consider a simple set class SSS and a measure μ\muμ defined on SSS.
  2. We extend the domain of μ\muμ from SSS to a larger one Ω=2Ω\Omega=2^\OmegaΩ=2Ω.
  3. We choose a subset from 2Ω2^\Omega2Ω, such that it is a σ\sigmaσ-field and μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is a measure defined on it.

In what follows, we illustrate the idea via constructing measures on Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd.

Semialgebra

Definition. A class of subsets S⊆2ΩS \subseteq 2^\OmegaS⊆2Ω is a semialgebra if

  1. It is closed under intersection: ∀A,B∈S\forall A, B \in S∀A,B∈S, A∩B∈SA \cap B \in SA∩B∈S.

  2. If A∈SA \in SA∈S, then Aˉ\bar AAˉ is a finite disjoint union of sets in SSS.

Examples. For d∈Z+d \in \mathbb{Z}^+d∈Z+, the collection of half-open intervals in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd plus the empty set

Sd≐{×i∈[d](ai,bi]:−∞≤ai<bi≤∞,∀i∈[d]}∪{∅} S_d \doteq \{ \times_{i \in [d] } (a_i, b_i] : -\infty \le a_i \lt b_i \le \infty, \forall i \in [d] \} \cup \{ \emptyset \} Sd​≐{×i∈[d]​(ai​,bi​]:−∞≤ai​<bi​≤∞,∀i∈[d]}∪{∅}

Algebra

Definition. A class of subsets F⊆2Ω\mathcal{F} \subseteq 2^\OmegaF⊆2Ω is an algebra (or field) if

  • It is closed under union, intersection and complement.

Remark. By De Morgan’s laws, A∩B‾=Aˉ∪Bˉ\overline{A \cap B } = \bar A \cup \bar BA∩B=Aˉ∪Bˉ and A∪B‾=Aˉ∩Bˉ\overline{A \cup B} = \bar A \cap \bar BA∪B=Aˉ∩Bˉ.
If we know a collection is closed under intersection (union) and complement, so is union (intersection).

Theorem If S⊆ΩS \subseteq \OmegaS⊆Ω is a semialgebra, then

S~≐{finite disjoint union of sets in S} \widetilde{S} \doteq \{ \text{finite disjoint union of sets in } S \} S≐{finite disjoint union of sets in S}

is an algebra.

Proof.

  1. S~\widetilde{S}S is closed under intersection: Let A,B∈S~A, B \in \widetilde{S}A,B∈S with A=+iAiA = +_i A_iA=+i​Ai​ and B=+jBjB = +_j B_jB=+j​Bj​, where +++ denotes disjoint union and Ai,Bj∈SA_i, B_j \in SAi​,Bj​∈S.
    Then A∩B=+i,jAi∩BjA \cap B = +_{i, j} A_i \cap B_jA∩B=+i,j​Ai​∩Bj​.
    As SSS is a semialgebra, it follows that Ai∩Bj∈SA_i \cap B_j \in SAi​∩Bj​∈S and A∩B∈S~A \cap B \in \widetilde{S}A∩B∈S.

  2. S~\widetilde{S}S is closed under complement. Let A∈S~A \in \widetilde{S}A∈S with A=+iAiA = +_i A_iA=+i​Ai​, where Ai∈SA_i \in SAi​∈S.
    Then Aˉ=∩iAˉi\bar A = \cap_i \bar A_iAˉ=∩i​Aˉi​.
    As SSS is a semialgebra, Aˉi\bar A_iAˉi​ is a finite disjoint union of sets in SSS, which implies that Aˉi∈S~\bar A_i \in \widetilde{S}Aˉi​∈S. Therefore Aˉ\bar AAˉ is a finite intersection of sets in S~\widetilde{S}S. Since S~\widetilde{S}S is closed under intersection, Aˉ∈S~\bar A \in \widetilde{S}Aˉ∈S.

□\square□

Measure Extension: Semialgebra →\rightarrow→ Algebra

Theorem. Let SSS be a semialgebra and μ\muμ be a measure on SSS. Then μ\muμ has a unique extension μˉ\bar \muμˉ​ that is a measure on S~\widetilde SS, the algebra generated by SSS.

Remark. The σ\sigmaσ-additivity condition of μ\muμ being a measure can be replaced by

  1. Finite additivity. If A,Ai∈SA, A_i \in SA,Ai​∈S with A=+iAiA = +_i A_iA=+i​Ai​, then μ(A)=∑iμ(Ai)\mu(A) = \sum_i \mu (A_i)μ(A)=∑i​μ(Ai​).
  2. Subadditivity. If A,Ai∈SA, A_i \in SA,Ai​∈S with A=+i≥1AiA = +_{i \ge 1} A_iA=+i≥1​Ai​, then μ(A)≤∑i≥1μ(Ai)\mu (A) \le \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu (A_i)μ(A)≤∑i≥1​μ(Ai​).

The subscript i≥1i \ge 1i≥1 in the conditions indicates a countable union, while a plain subscript iii or jjj indicates a finite union.

The relation between the condition stated in the Theorem and the relaxed ones is established as follows.

Exercise. A finitely additive nonnegative set function on an algebra S~\widetilde{S}S is monotone and the following conditions are equivalent

  1. σ\sigmaσ-additivity.
  2. Subadditivity.

The proof for the Theorem consists of two steps.

▶\blacktriangleright▶ Defining μˉ\bar \muμˉ​

If μ\muμ is finitely additive in SSS, then it has a finitely additive extension μˉ\bar \muμˉ​ in S~\widetilde{S}S.

  1. Extension. If A=+iAi∈S~A = +_i A_i \in \widetilde{S}A=+i​Ai​∈S with Ai∈SA_i \in SAi​∈S, define

    μˉ(A)=∑iμ(Ai). \bar \mu(A) = \sum_i \mu (A_i). μˉ​(A)=i∑​μ(Ai​).

    We need to verify the value of μˉ(A)\bar \mu(A)μˉ​(A) is unique.
    Suppose AAA has another decomposition: A=+jBjA = +_j B_jA=+j​Bj​ with Bj∈SB_j \in SBj​∈S.
    Since SSS is a semialgebra, Ai∩Bj∈SA_i \cap B_j \in SAi​∩Bj​∈S.
    Using that μ\muμ is a measure

    ∑iμ(Ai)=∑i,jμ(Ai∩Bj)=∑jμ(Bj). \sum_i \mu (A_i) = \sum_{i, j} \mu(A_i \cap B_j) = \sum_j \mu(B_j). i∑​μ(Ai​)=i,j∑​μ(Ai​∩Bj​)=j∑​μ(Bj​).

    It follows that μˉ(A)\bar \mu(A)μˉ​(A) does not change with the decomposition of AAA and hence is well-defined.

  2. Finite additivity. Let A=+iAi∈S~A = +_i A_i \in \widetilde{S}A=+i​Ai​∈S with Ai∈S~A_i \in \widetilde{S}Ai​∈S and suppose that Ai=+jBi,jA_i = +_j B_{i,j}Ai​=+j​Bi,j​ with Bj∈SB_j \in SBj​∈S.
    Then A=+i,jBi,jA = +_{i,j} B_{i,j}A=+i,j​Bi,j​.
    By definition of μˉ(A)\bar \mu (A)μˉ​(A) and μˉ(Ai)\bar \mu (A_i)μˉ​(Ai​),

μˉ(A)=∑i,jμ(Bi,j)=∑iμˉ(Ai). \bar \mu (A) = \sum_{i,j} \mu (B_{i,j}) = \sum_{i} \bar \mu ( A_i ). μˉ​(A)=i,j∑​μ(Bi,j​)=i∑​μˉ​(Ai​).

We list two more properties about μˉ\bar \muμˉ​ induced by finite additivity.

  • Monotonicity. If A,B∈S~A, B \in \widetilde{S}A,B∈S with A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B, then μˉ(A)≤μˉ(B)\bar \mu (A) \le \bar \mu (B)μˉ​(A)≤μˉ​(B). As S~\widetilde{S}S is an algebra, B−A∈S~B - A \in \widetilde{S}B−A∈S and by finite additivity of μˉ\bar \muμˉ​,

    μˉ(A)≤μˉ(A)+μˉ(B−A)=μˉ(B). \bar \mu (A) \le \bar \mu (A) + \bar \mu (B - A) = \bar \mu (B). μˉ​(A)≤μˉ​(A)+μˉ​(B−A)=μˉ​(B).

  • Finite subadditivity. If A⊆∪i∈[n]AiA \subseteq \cup_{i \in [n] } A_iA⊆∪i∈[n]​Ai​ with A∈S~A \in \widetilde{S}A∈S, Ai∈S~,∀i∈[n]A_i \in \widetilde{S}, \forall i \in [n]Ai​∈S,∀i∈[n], then μˉ(A)≤∑iμˉ(Ai)\bar \mu(A) \le \sum_i \bar \mu (A_i)μˉ​(A)≤∑i​μˉ​(Ai​). Let B1=A1B_1 = A_1B1​=A1​ and Bi=Ai−Ai−1−…−A1B_i = A_i - A_{i - 1} - \ldots - A_1Bi​=Ai​−Ai−1​−…−A1​ for i≥1i \ge 1i≥1. As S~\widetilde{S}S is an algebra, Bi∈S~B_i \in \widetilde{S}Bi​∈S. By monotonicity and finite additivity of μˉ\bar \muμˉ​,

    μˉ(A)≤μˉ(+iBi)=∑iμˉ(Bi)≤∑iμˉ(Ai). \bar \mu (A) \le \bar \mu( +_i B_i ) = \sum_i \bar \mu (B_i) \le \sum_i \bar \mu (A_i). μˉ​(A)≤μˉ​(+i​Bi​)=i∑​μˉ​(Bi​)≤i∑​μˉ​(Ai​).

□\square□

▶\blacktriangleright▶ σ\sigmaσ-Additivity of μˉ\bar \muμˉ​

If A,A1,…∈S~A, A_1, \ldots \in \widetilde SA,A1​,…∈S with A=+i≥1AiA = +_{i \ge 1} A_iA=+i≥1​Ai​, then

μˉ(A)=∑i≥1μˉ(Ai).\small \bar \mu (A) = \sum_{i \ge 1} \bar \mu (A_i). μˉ​(A)=i≥1∑​μˉ​(Ai​).

Proof. Let Ai=+jBi,jA_i = +_j B_{i,j}Ai​=+j​Bi,j​ with Bi,j∈SB_{i,j} \in SBi,j​∈S.
Then A=+i,jBi,jA = +_{i,j} B_{i,j}A=+i,j​Bi,j​ and ∑i≥1μˉ(Ai)=∑i≥1∑jμ(Bi,j)\sum_{i \ge 1} \bar \mu(A_i) = \sum_{i \ge 1} \sum_j \mu ( B_{i,j} )∑i≥1​μˉ​(Ai​)=∑i≥1​∑j​μ(Bi,j​).
WLOG, we assume that AiA_iAi​ are countable union of disjoint sets in SSS.

Next, assume that A=+kCkA = +_k C_kA=+k​Ck​ with Ck∈SC_k \in SCk​∈S.
Using that SSS is closed under intersection, and that μ\muμ is a measure on SSS (therefore σ\sigmaσ-additivity holds),

μ(Ck)=∑i≥1μ(Ck∩Ai). \mu(C_k) = \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu (C_k \cap A_i). μ(Ck​)=i≥1∑​μ(Ck​∩Ai​).

Observing that nonnegative numbers can be summed in any order,

μˉ(A)=∑kμ(Ck)=∑k∑i≥1μ(Ck∩Ai)=∑i≥1∑kμ(Ck∩Ai)=∑i≥1μ(Ai). \small \begin{aligned} \bar \mu(A) = \sum_k \mu (C_k) = \sum_k \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu (C_k \cap A_i) = \sum_{i \ge 1} \sum_k \mu (C_k \cap A_i) = \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu (A_i). \end{aligned} μˉ​(A)=k∑​μ(Ck​)=k∑​i≥1∑​μ(Ck​∩Ai​)=i≥1∑​k∑​μ(Ck​∩Ai​)=i≥1∑​μ(Ai​).​

□\square□

Measure Extension: Algebra →\rightarrow→ σ\sigmaσ-Algebra

Definition. μˉ\bar \muμˉ​ is said to be σ\sigmaσ-finite if there is a sequence of sets Ai∈S~A_i \in \widetilde{S}Ai​∈S such that μ(Ai)<∞\mu(A_i) < \inftyμ(Ai​)<∞ and ∪i≥1Ai=Ω\cup_{i \ge 1} A_i = \Omega∪i≥1​Ai​=Ω.

Caratheodory’s Extension Theorem.
Let μˉ\bar \muμˉ​ be a σ\sigmaσ-finite measure on an algebra S~\widetilde SS.
Then μˉ\bar \muμˉ​ has a unique extension μ∗\mu^*μ∗ (that is a measure) to σ(S~)\sigma(\widetilde S)σ(S), the smallest σ\sigmaσ-field containing S~\widetilde SS.

Remark: Observe that σ(S~)=σ(S)\sigma(\widetilde S) = \sigma(S)σ(S)=σ(S).

The proof is included at the end of the article.

Lebesgue-Stieltjes Measure

In this section, we construct concrete measures on Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd.

Definition. A function F:R→RF: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}F:R→R is a Stieltjes measure function if

  1. FFF is non-decreasing.

  2. FFF is right continuous, i.e., lim⁡y↓xF(y)=F(x)\lim_{y \downarrow x} F(y) = F(x)limy↓x​F(y)=F(x).

Definition (Borel Sets). Let Rd=σ(Sd)\mathcal{R}^d = \sigma (S_d)Rd=σ(Sd​). It is the smallest σ\sigmaσ-field containing all open sets in Rd\mathbb{R}^dRd.

Theorem 3. Associated with each Stieltjes measure function FFF there is a unique measure μ\muμ on (R,R1)(\mathbb{R},\mathcal{R}^1)(R,R1) with

μ((a,b])=F(b)−F(a). \mu \big( (a, b] \big) = F(b) - F(a). μ((a,b])=F(b)−F(a).

When F(x)=xF(x) = xF(x)=x, the measure μ\muμ is called Lebesgue measure.

Proof. We just to verity that μ\muμ is a measure defined on the following semi-algebra:

S1≐{(a,b]:−∞≤a<b≤∞}∪{∅}. S_1 \doteq \{ (a, b] : -\infty \le a \lt b \le \infty \} \cup \{ \emptyset \}. S1​≐{(a,b]:−∞≤a<b≤∞}∪{∅}.

  1. μ((a,b])≥0\mu((a, b]) \ge 0μ((a,b])≥0, since FFF is non-decreasing.

  2. Finite additivity. If (a,b]=+i(ai,bi](a, b] = +_i (a_i, b_i](a,b]=+i​(ai​,bi​], μ((a,b])=∑iμ((ai,bi])\mu \big( (a, b] \big) = \sum_i \mu \big( ( a_i, b_i ] \big)μ((a,b])=∑i​μ((ai​,bi​]). We can rearrange the {(ai,bi]}\{ (a_i, b_i] \}{(ai​,bi​]}, such that a=a1a = a_1a=a1​, bi=ai+1b_i = a_{i + 1}bi​=ai+1​ for all 1≤i<n1 \le i < n1≤i<n, and bn=bb_n = bbn​=b. Hence,

    μ((a,b])=F(b)−F(a)=∑i(F(bi)−F(ai))=∑iμ((ai,bi]). \mu \big( (a, b] \big) = F(b) - F(a) = \sum_i ( F(b_i) - F(a_i) ) = \sum_i \mu \big( ( a_i, b_i ] \big). μ((a,b])=F(b)−F(a)=i∑​(F(bi​)−F(ai​))=i∑​μ((ai​,bi​]).

  3. Finite subadditivity. If (a,b]⊆∪i∈[n](ai,bi](a, b] \subseteq \cup_{i \in [n] } (a_i, b_i](a,b]⊆∪i∈[n]​(ai​,bi​], μ((a,b])≤∑i∈[n]μ((ai,bi])\mu \big( (a, b] \big) \le \sum_{i \in [ n ] } \mu \big( ( a_i, b_i ] \big)μ((a,b])≤∑i∈[n]​μ((ai​,bi​]).
    Recall that the definition of μˉ\bar \muμˉ​ only requires finite additivity of μ\muμ.
    Working with S1~\widetilde{S_1}S1​​ and μˉ\bar \muμˉ​ significantly simplifies the proof.
    As for all A∈S1A \in S_1A∈S1​, it holds that μ(A)=μˉ(A)\mu(A) = \bar \mu(A)μ(A)=μˉ​(A).
    It suffices to prove that

    μˉ((a,b])≤∑i∈[n]μˉ((ai,bi]). \bar \mu \big( (a, b] \big) \le \sum_{i \in [ n ] } \bar \mu \big( (a_i, b_i] \big). μˉ​((a,b])≤i∈[n]∑​μˉ​((ai​,bi​]).

    But this follows exactly from finite subadditivity of μˉ\bar \muμˉ​.

  4. σ\sigmaσ-additivity. If (a,b]=+i≥1(ai,bi](a, b] = +_{i \ge 1} (a_i, b_i](a,b]=+i≥1​(ai​,bi​], then μ((a,b])=∑i≥1μ((ai,bi])\mu \big( (a, b] \big) = \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu \big( ( a_i, b_i ] \big)μ((a,b])=∑i≥1​μ((ai​,bi​]).
    Using finite subadditivity of μ\muμ, for all n∈Z+n \in \mathbb{Z}^+n∈Z+,

    μ((a,b])≥∑i∈[n]μ((ai,bi]). \mu \big( (a, b] \big) \ge \sum_{i \in [n] } \mu \big( ( a_i, b_i ] \big). μ((a,b])≥i∈[n]∑​μ((ai​,bi​]).

    Letting n→∞n \rightarrow \inftyn→∞, we get
    μ((a,b])≥∑i≥1μ((ai,bi])\mu \big( (a, b] \big) \ge \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu \big( ( a_i, b_i ] \big)μ((a,b])≥∑i≥1​μ((ai​,bi​]).

    It is left to prove the reverse direction of the inequality (σ\sigmaσ-subadditivity).
    If μ((ai,bi])=∞\mu \big( ( a_i, b_i ] \big) = \inftyμ((ai​,bi​])=∞ for some iii, then the inequality is trivial.
    WLOG, assume that −∞<ai<bi<∞-\infty < a_i < b_i < \infty−∞<ai​<bi​<∞ for all iii.

    First, suppose that both aaa and bbb are finite.
    For each ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, as FFF is right continuous, there exists some δ>0\delta > 0δ>0, such that

    F(a+δ)≤F(a)+ϵ , and μ((a,b])≤μ((a+δ,b])+ϵ. \begin{aligned} F(a + \delta) &\le F(a) + \epsilon\,,\qquad \text{ and } \\ \mu \Big( (a, b] \Big) &\le \mu \Big( (a + \delta, b] \Big) + \epsilon. \end{aligned} F(a+δ)μ((a,b])​≤F(a)+ϵ, and ≤μ((a+δ,b])+ϵ.​

    For each iii, there exists some δi>0\delta_i > 0δi​>0, such that

    F(bi+δi)≤F(bi)+ϵ/2i , and μ((ai,bi+δi])≤μ((ai,bi])+ϵ/2i. \begin{aligned} F(b_i + \delta_i) &\le F(b_i) + \epsilon / 2^i\,,\qquad \text{ and } \\ \mu \Big( (a_i, b_i + \delta_i] \Big) &\le \mu \Big( (a_i, b_i] \Big) + \epsilon / 2^i. \end{aligned} F(bi​+δi​)μ((ai​,bi​+δi​])​≤F(bi​)+ϵ/2i, and ≤μ((ai​,bi​])+ϵ/2i.​

    Since {(ai,bi+δi)}\{ (a_i, b_i + \delta_i) \}{(ai​,bi​+δi​)} is an open cover of the closed interval [a+δ,b][a + \delta, b][a+δ,b], there is a finite sub-cover {(si,ti)}\{ (s_i, t_i) \}{(si​,ti​)}.
    It follows that {(si,ti]}\{ (s_i, t_i] \}{(si​,ti​]} covers (a+δ,b](a + \delta, b](a+δ,b]. Therefore,

    μ((a+δ,b])≤∑iμ((si,ti])≤∑i≥1μ((ai,bi+δi]) \mu \Big( (a + \delta, b] \Big) \le \sum_i \mu \Big( (s_i, t_i] \Big) \le \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu \Big( (a_i, b_i + \delta_i] \Big) μ((a+δ,b])≤i∑​μ((si​,ti​])≤i≥1∑​μ((ai​,bi​+δi​])

    It follows that

    μ((a,b])≤∑i≥1μ((ai,bi])+2ϵ. \mu \Big( (a, b] \Big) \le \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu \Big( (a_i, b_i] \Big) + 2 \epsilon. μ((a,b])≤i≥1∑​μ((ai​,bi​])+2ϵ.

    Letting ϵ→0\epsilon \rightarrow 0ϵ→0 finishes the proof.

    If a=−∞a = -\inftya=−∞ or b=∞b = \inftyb=∞, the inequality
    μ((a′,b′])≤∑i≥1μ((ai,bi])\small \mu \Big( (a', b'] \Big) \le \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu \Big( (a_i, b_i] \Big)μ((a′,b′])≤∑i≥1​μ((ai​,bi​])
    holds for all finite subset (a′,b′]⊆(a,b](a', b'] \subseteq (a, b](a′,b′]⊆(a,b].
    Hence it holds for (a,b](a, b](a,b].

□\square□

Caratheodory’s Extension Theorem

Caratheodory’s Extension Theorem.
Let μˉ\bar \muμˉ​ be a σ\sigmaσ-finite measure on an algebra S~\widetilde SS.
Then μˉ\bar \muμˉ​ has a unique extension μ∗\mu^*μ∗ (that is a measure) to σ(S~)\sigma(\widetilde S)σ(S), the smallest σ\sigmaσ-field containing S~\widetilde SS.

♠\spadesuit♠ Outer Measure

Define the function μ∗:2Ω→R≥0\mu^*: 2^\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}_{\ge 0}μ∗:2Ω→R≥0​ as ∀A⊆Ω\forall A \subseteq \Omega∀A⊆Ω,

μ∗(A)=inf⁡{∑i≥1μˉ(Ai):A⊆∪i≥1Ai and Ai∈S~ ,∀i} \mu^*(A) = \inf \left\{ \sum_{i \ge 1} \bar{ \mu }(A_i) : A \subseteq \cup_{i \ge 1} A_i \text{ and } A_i \in \widetilde{S}\,,\forall i \right\} μ∗(A)=inf{i≥1∑​μˉ​(Ai​):A⊆∪i≥1​Ai​ and Ai​∈S,∀i}

Intuitively, μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is an upper bound on the measure of AAA.
The following properties follows immediately form the definition.

  1. μ∗(∅)≤∑i=1∞μˉ(∅)=0\mu^*(\emptyset) \le \sum_{i = 1}^\infty \bar{ \mu }(\emptyset) = 0μ∗(∅)≤∑i=1∞​μˉ​(∅)=0.

  2. μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is monotone: A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B implies that μ∗(A)≤μ∗(B)\mu^*(A) \le \mu^*(B)μ∗(A)≤μ∗(B).

  3. Subadditivity. If A⊆∪i≥1AiA \subseteq \cup_{i \ge 1} A_iA⊆∪i≥1​Ai​, then μ∗(A)≤∑i≥1μ∗(Ai)\mu^*(A) \le \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu^*(A_i)μ∗(A)≤∑i≥1​μ∗(Ai​).
    Given ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, for each AiA_iAi​, there exists a countable sequence {Bi,j:j∈Z+}\{ B_{i, j} : j \in \mathbb{Z}^+ \}{Bi,j​:j∈Z+} in S~\widetilde{S}S such that it covers AiA_iAi​ and

    ∑j≥1μˉ(Bi,j)≤μ∗(Ai)+ϵ/2i. \sum_{j \ge 1} \bar{ \mu }(B_{i, j}) \le \mu^*(A_i) + \epsilon / 2^i. j≥1∑​μˉ​(Bi,j​)≤μ∗(Ai​)+ϵ/2i.

    The sequence {Bi,j:i,j∈Z+}\{ B_{i, j} : i, j \in \mathbb{Z}^+ \}{Bi,j​:i,j∈Z+} is countable and covers AAA.
    Further

    μ∗(A)≤∑i≥1∑j≥1μˉ(Bi,j)≤∑i≥1μ∗(Ai)+ϵ. \mu^*( A ) \le \sum_{i \ge 1} \sum_{j \ge 1} \bar{ \mu }(B_{i, j}) \le \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu^* (A_i) + \epsilon. μ∗(A)≤i≥1∑​j≥1∑​μˉ​(Bi,j​)≤i≥1∑​μ∗(Ai​)+ϵ.

    The inequality holds for all ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 hence it holds that

    μ∗(A)≤∑i≥1μ∗(Ai). \mu^*( A ) \le \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu^* (A_i). μ∗(A)≤i≥1∑​μ∗(Ai​).

Now, μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is almost a measure: it is an nonnegative set function and satisfies subadditivity. By previous analysis, we know that

Given a nonnegative, finitely additive set function defined on an algebra, the following conditions are equivalent

  • σ\sigmaσ-additivity.
  • σ\sigmaσ-subadditivity.

If we can prove that μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is finitely additive, then it is a measure on the σ\sigmaσ-algebra, 2Ω2^\Omega2Ω (which is also an algebra). However, in general, finite additivity does not hold on 2Ω2^\Omega2Ω. Therefore, we restrict our discussion on a subset of 2Ω2^\Omega2Ω.

Measurable Set

Intuitively, the measurable sets are the ones on which finite additivity of μ∗\mu^*μ∗ holds.
Formally, we say that a set A⊆ΩA \subseteq \OmegaA⊆Ω is called measurable if

μ∗(B)=μ∗(B∩A)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ),∀B⊆Ω. \mu^* (B) = \mu^* (B \cap A) + \mu^* (B \cap \bar A),\qquad \forall B \subseteq \Omega. μ∗(B)=μ∗(B∩A)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ),∀B⊆Ω.

Using subadditivity, to prove AAA is measurable, it is enough to show that

μ∗(B)≥μ∗(B∩A)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ),∀B⊆Ω. \mu^* (B) \ge \mu^* (B \cap A) + \mu^* (B \cap \bar A),\qquad \forall B \subseteq \Omega. μ∗(B)≥μ∗(B∩A)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ),∀B⊆Ω.

Definition. S∗=S^* =S∗= { the collection of all measurable sets }.

Theorem. S∗S^*S∗ is a σ\sigmaσ-field that contains S~\widetilde{S}S and the restriction of μ∗\mu^*μ∗ to S∗S^*S∗ is a measure.

▶S∗\blacktriangleright \quad S^*▶S∗ is a σ\sigmaσ-field

  1. If A∈S∗A \in S^*A∈S∗, then so is Aˉ\bar AAˉ.

    Proof. By definition.

  2. If A1,A2∈S∗A_1, A_2 \in S^*A1​,A2​∈S∗, then A1∪A2∈S∗A_1 \cup A_2 \in S^*A1​∪A2​∈S∗ and A1∩A2∈S∗A_1 \cap A_2 \in S^*A1​∩A2​∈S∗.

    Proof. Observe that

    A1∪A2⊆(A1∩Aˉ2)∪(A1∩A2)∪(Aˉ1∩A2). A_1 \cup A_2 \subseteq (A_1 \cap \bar A_2) \cup (A_1 \cap A_2) \cup (\bar A_1 \cap A_2). A1​∪A2​⊆(A1​∩Aˉ2​)∪(A1​∩A2​)∪(Aˉ1​∩A2​).

    For all B⊆ΩB \subseteq \OmegaB⊆Ω, it holds that

    μ∗(B)=μ∗(B∩A1)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ1)=μ∗(B∩A1∩A2)+μ∗(B∩A1∩Aˉ2)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ1∩A2)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ1∩Aˉ2)≥μ∗(B∩(A1∪A2))++μ∗(B∩Aˉ1∩Aˉ2) \begin{aligned} \mu^*(B) &= \mu^*(B \cap A_1) + \mu^* (B \cap \bar A_1) \\ &= \mu^*(B \cap A_1 \cap A_2 ) + \mu^*(B \cap A_1 \cap \bar A_2 ) \\ &\quad + \mu^* (B \cap \bar A_1 \cap A_2 ) + \mu^* (B \cap \bar A_1 \cap \bar A_2 ) \\ &\ge \mu^*(B \cap (A_1 \cup A_2) ) + + \mu^* (B \cap \bar A_1 \cap \bar A_2 ) \end{aligned} μ∗(B)​=μ∗(B∩A1​)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ1​)=μ∗(B∩A1​∩A2​)+μ∗(B∩A1​∩Aˉ2​)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ1​∩A2​)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ1​∩Aˉ2​)≥μ∗(B∩(A1​∪A2​))++μ∗(B∩Aˉ1​∩Aˉ2​)​

    The last inequality follows form subadditivity of μ∗\mu^*μ∗.
    Hence A1∪A2∈S∗A_1 \cup A_2 \in S^*A1​∪A2​∈S∗. Finally, A1∩A2=Aˉ1∪Aˉ2‾∈S∗A_1 \cap A_2 = \overline{ \bar A_1 \cup \bar A_2} \in S^*A1​∩A2​=Aˉ1​∪Aˉ2​​∈S∗.

    □\square□

  3. If Ai∈S∗A_i \in S^*Ai​∈S∗, then A=∪i≥1Ai∈S∗A = \cup_{i \ge 1} A_i \in S^*A=∪i≥1​Ai​∈S∗.

    Proof. We have proven that S∗S^*S∗ is an algebra.
    Let B1=A1B_1 = A_1B1​=A1​ and Bi=Ai−Ai−1−…−A1B_i = A_i - A_{i - 1} - \ldots - A_1Bi​=Ai​−Ai−1​−…−A1​ for i≥2i \ge 2i≥2.
    It holds that Bi∈S∗B_i \in S^*Bi​∈S∗ and ∪iAi=∪Bi\cup_i A_i = \cup B_i∪i​Ai​=∪Bi​. Replacing AiA_iAi​ with BiB_iBi​ we can assume without lose of generality that the AiA_iAi​ are disjoint.
    For all n∈Z+n \in \mathbb{Z}^+n∈Z+, let Cn=+i∈[n]AiC_n = +_{i \in [n] } A_iCn​=+i∈[n]​Ai​.
    For all B⊆ΩB \subseteq \OmegaB⊆Ω and n>1n > 1n>1,

    μ∗(B)=μ∗(B∩Cn)+μ∗(B∩Cˉn)=μ∗(B∩Cn∩An)+μ∗(B∩Cn∩Aˉn)+μ∗(B∩Cˉn)=μ∗(B∩An)+μ∗(B∩Cn−1)+μ∗(B∩Cˉn) \begin{array}{ll} \mu^*(B) &= \mu^* (B \cap C_n ) + \mu^* (B \cap \bar C_n ) \\ &= \mu^* (B \cap C_n \cap A_n ) + \mu^* (B \cap C_n \cap \bar A_n ) + \mu^* (B \cap \bar C_n ) \\ &= \mu^* (B \cap A_n ) + \mu^* (B \cap C_{n - 1} ) + \mu^* (B \cap \bar C_n ) \\ \end{array} μ∗(B)​=μ∗(B∩Cn​)+μ∗(B∩Cˉn​)=μ∗(B∩Cn​∩An​)+μ∗(B∩Cn​∩Aˉn​)+μ∗(B∩Cˉn​)=μ∗(B∩An​)+μ∗(B∩Cn−1​)+μ∗(B∩Cˉn​)​

    The last equality follows from that Cn∩An=AnC_n \cap A_n = A_nCn​∩An​=An​ and Cn∩Aˉn=Cn−1C_n \cap \bar A_n = C_{n - 1}Cn​∩Aˉn​=Cn−1​.
    By induction, and monotonicity of μ∗\mu^*μ∗, we get

    μ∗(B)=∑i∈[n]μ∗(B∩Ai)+μ∗(B∩Cˉn)≥∑i∈[n]μ∗(B∩Ai)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ) \begin{array}{ll} \mu^*(B) &= \sum_{i \in [n] } \mu^* (B \cap A_i ) + \mu^* (B \cap \bar C_n ) \\ &\ge \sum_{i \in [n] } \mu^* (B \cap A_i ) + \mu^* (B \cap \bar A ) \end{array} μ∗(B)​=∑i∈[n]​μ∗(B∩Ai​)+μ∗(B∩Cˉn​)≥∑i∈[n]​μ∗(B∩Ai​)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ)​

    Letting n→∞n \rightarrow \inftyn→∞ finishes the proof.

    □\square□

▶S∗⊇S~\blacktriangleright \quad S^* \supseteq \widetilde{S}▶S∗⊇S

Proof. For all B⊆ΩB \subseteq \OmegaB⊆Ω, and all ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, there exists a sequence {Bi}\{ B_i \}{Bi​} in S~\widetilde{S}S, such that B⊆∪iBiB \subseteq \cup_i B_iB⊆∪i​Bi​ and

μ∗(B)+ϵ≥∑i≥1μˉ(Bi). \begin{array}{ll} \mu^* (B) + \epsilon \ge \sum_{i \ge 1} \bar \mu (B_i). \end{array} μ∗(B)+ϵ≥∑i≥1​μˉ​(Bi​).​

Let A∈S~A \in \widetilde{S}A∈S. Observe that Bi∩A,Bi∩Aˉ∈S~B_i \cap A, B_i \cap \bar A \in \widetilde{S}Bi​∩A,Bi​∩Aˉ∈S, and that

B∩A⊆∪i(Bi∩A) ,B∩Aˉ⊆∪i(Bi∩Aˉ). \begin{array}{ll} B \cap A \subseteq \cup_i (B_i \cap A)\,, \qquad B \cap \bar A \subseteq \cup_i (B_i \cap \bar A). \end{array} B∩A⊆∪i​(Bi​∩A),B∩Aˉ⊆∪i​(Bi​∩Aˉ).​

By the definition of μ∗\mu^*μ∗ and finite additivity of μˉ\bar \muμˉ​, it holds that

μ∗(B∩A)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ)≤∑i≥1μˉ(Bi∩A)+∑i≥1μˉ(Bi∩Aˉ)=∑i≥1μˉ(Bi). \small \begin{aligned} \mu^* (B \cap A) + \mu^* (B \cap \bar A) \le \sum_{i \ge 1} \bar \mu (B_i \cap A) + \sum_{i \ge 1} \bar \mu (B_i \cap \bar A) = \sum_{i \ge 1 } \bar \mu (B_i). \end{aligned} μ∗(B∩A)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ)≤i≥1∑​μˉ​(Bi​∩A)+i≥1∑​μˉ​(Bi​∩Aˉ)=i≥1∑​μˉ​(Bi​).​

Letting ϵ→0\epsilon \rightarrow 0ϵ→0, it concludes that

μ∗(B)≥μ∗(B∩A)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ). \mu^*(B) \ge \mu^* (B \cap A) + \mu^* (B \cap \bar A). μ∗(B)≥μ∗(B∩A)+μ∗(B∩Aˉ).

□\square□

▶μ∗\blacktriangleright \quad \mu^*▶μ∗ is a measure restricted to S∗S^*S∗

Sigma additivity of μ∗\mu^*μ∗. Let A=+i≥1AiA = +_{i \ge 1} A_iA=+i≥1​Ai​, with Ai∈S∗A_i \in S^*Ai​∈S∗, then

μ∗(A)=∑i≥1μ∗(Ai). \mu^*(A) = \sum_{i \ge 1 } \mu^*( A_i ). μ∗(A)=i≥1∑​μ∗(Ai​).

Proof. As S∗S^*S∗ is an algebra and μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is σ\sigmaσ-subadditive, it suffices to prove that μ∗\mu^*μ∗ is finitely additive. Let A=+i∈[n]AiA = +_{i \in [n] } A_iA=+i∈[n]​Ai​.

μ∗(A)=μ∗(A∩An)+μ∗(A∩Aˉn)=μ∗(An)+μ∗(+i∈[n−1]Ai)… =∑i∈[n]μ∗(Ai). \begin{aligned} \mu^*(A) &= \mu^*(A \cap A_n) + \mu^*(A \cap \bar A_n) \\ &= \mu^*(A_n) + \mu^*( +_{i \in [n - 1] } A_i ) \\ &\ldots\, \\ &= \sum_{ i \in [n] } \mu^* (A_i). \end{aligned} μ∗(A)​=μ∗(A∩An​)+μ∗(A∩Aˉn​)=μ∗(An​)+μ∗(+i∈[n−1]​Ai​)…=i∈[n]∑​μ∗(Ai​).​

□\square□

♠\spadesuit♠ Uniqueness

▶  π\blacktriangleright\,\,\pi▶π-system

Definition. P\mathcal{P}P is said to be a π\piπ-system if it is closed under intersection.

▶  λ\blacktriangleright\,\,\lambda▶λ-system

Definition. L\mathcal{L}L is said to be a λ\lambdaλ-system if
(1). Ω∈L\Omega \in \mathcal{L}Ω∈L.
(2). If A∈LA \in \mathcal{L}A∈L, then Aˉ∈L\bar A \in \mathcal{L}Aˉ∈L.
(3). If A1,A2,…∈LA_1, A_2, \ldots \in \mathcal{L}A1​,A2​,…∈L with An∩Am=∅A_n \cap A_m = \emptysetAn​∩Am​=∅ for n≠mn \neq mn=m, then ∪n≥1An∈L\cup_{n \ge 1} A_n \in \mathcal{L}∪n≥1​An​∈L.

Note that a λ\lambdaλ-system is almost a σ\sigmaσ-algebra, expect that it is only closed under disjoint union.

Lemma. Replacing (2) in the definition with the following one results in equivalent definition
(2’). If A,B∈LA, B \in \mathcal{L}A,B∈L with A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B, then B−A∈LB - A \in \mathcal{L}B−A∈L.

Proof.

Assume that (1), (2), (3) hold.
If A,B∈LA, B \in \mathcal{L}A,B∈L with A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B, then

Bˉ∈L  ⟹  A∪Bˉ∈L  ⟹  A∪Bˉ‾=B−A∈L. \bar B \in \mathcal{L} \implies A \cup \bar B \in \mathcal{L} \implies \overline{A \cup \bar B} = B - A \in \mathcal{L}. Bˉ∈L⟹A∪Bˉ∈L⟹A∪Bˉ=B−A∈L.

Hence (2’) holds.

Assume that (1), (2’), (3) hold.
Since Ω∈L\Omega \in \mathcal{L}Ω∈L, if A∈LA \in \mathcal{L}A∈L, then

Aˉ=Ω−A∈L. \bar A = \Omega - A \in \mathcal{L}. Aˉ=Ω−A∈L.

Hence (2) holds.

□\square□

Lemma. If a λ\lambdaλ-system L\mathcal{L}L is closed under intersection, then it is a σ\sigmaσ-field.

Proof. Since it is closed under complement and intersection, it is an algebra. It is a σ\sigmaσ-field as it satisfies monotonicity.

□\square□

▶  \blacktriangleright\,\,▶ π-λ\pi \text{-} \lambdaπ-λ Lemma

π-λ\pi \text{-} \lambdaπ-λ Lemma. Let P\mathcal{P}P be a π\piπ system and L\mathcal{L}L be a λ\lambdaλ-system.
If P⊆L\mathcal{P} \subseteq \mathcal{L}P⊆L, then σ(P)⊆L\sigma(\mathcal{P}) \subseteq \mathcal{L}σ(P)⊆L.

Proof. Let λ(P)\lambda(\mathcal{P})λ(P) the smallest λ\lambdaλ-system that contains P\mathcal{P}P.
We will show that λ(P)\lambda(\mathcal{P})λ(P) is a σ\sigmaσ-field. Then

σ(P)⊆λ(P)⊆L. \sigma(\mathcal{P}) \subseteq \lambda(\mathcal{P}) \subseteq \mathcal{L}. σ(P)⊆λ(P)⊆L.

It suffices to prove that λ(P)\lambda(\mathcal{P})λ(P) is a π\piπ-system.

​For each A∈λ(P)A \in \lambda (\mathcal{P})A∈λ(P), define

ΠA≐{B∈λ(P):B∩A∈λ(P)}. \Pi_A \doteq \{ B \in \lambda (\mathcal{P}) : B \cap A \in \lambda (\mathcal{P}) \}. ΠA​≐{B∈λ(P):B∩A∈λ(P)}.

We will prove that ΠA\Pi_AΠA​ is a λ\lambdaλ-system and ΠA⊇P\Pi_A \supseteq \mathcal{P}ΠA​⊇P.
It follows that ΠA⊇λ(P)\Pi_A \supseteq \lambda(\mathcal{P})ΠA​⊇λ(P) and λ(P)\lambda(\mathcal{P})λ(P) is closed under intersection, and therefore a π\piπ-system.

ΠA\Pi_AΠA​ is a λ\lambdaλ-system:

  1. Ω∈ΠA\Omega \in \Pi_AΩ∈ΠA​.

  2. If B∈ΠAB \in \Pi_AB∈ΠA​, we need to prove that Bˉ∈ΠA\bar B \in \Pi_ABˉ∈ΠA​. We need to prove that A∩Bˉ=A−(A∩B)∈λ(P)A \cap \bar B = A - \big( A \cap B \big) \in \lambda(\mathcal{P})A∩Bˉ=A−(A∩B)∈λ(P).
    This follows from definition (2’) of λ\lambdaλ-system and that

    A,(A∩B)∈λ(P) ∧ A⊇(A∩B). A, \big( A \cap B \big) \in \lambda(\mathcal{P})\, \wedge\, A \supseteq \big( A \cap B \big). A,(A∩B)∈λ(P)∧A⊇(A∩B).

  3. If B1,B2,…∈ΠAB_1, B_2, \ldots \in \Pi_AB1​,B2​,…∈ΠA​ with Bn∩Bm=∅B_n \cap B_m = \emptysetBn​∩Bm​=∅, then ∪n≥1Bn∈ΠA\cup_{n \ge 1} B_n\in \Pi_A∪n≥1​Bn​∈ΠA​, since

(∪n≥1Bn)∩A=∪n≥1(Bn∩A)∈λ(P). \big( \cup_{n \ge 1} B_n \big) \cap A = \cup_{n \ge 1} (B_n \cap A) \in \lambda (\mathcal{P}). (∪n≥1​Bn​)∩A=∪n≥1​(Bn​∩A)∈λ(P).

ΠA\Pi_AΠA​ contains P\mathcal{P}P:

If B∈PB \in \mathcal{P}B∈P, denote ΠB={A⊆Ω:A∩B∈λ(P)}\Pi_B = \{ A \subseteq \Omega : A \cap B \in \lambda (\mathcal{P}) \}ΠB​={A⊆Ω:A∩B∈λ(P)}. Since P\mathcal{P}P is closed under intersection, ΠB⊇P\Pi_B \supseteq \mathcal{P}ΠB​⊇P. Since ΠB\Pi_BΠB​ is a λ\lambdaλ-system, ΠB⊇λ(P)\Pi_B \supseteq \lambda (\mathcal{P})ΠB​⊇λ(P).

Hence, for all A∈λ(P),B∈PA \in \lambda (\mathcal{P}), B \in \mathcal{P}A∈λ(P),B∈P, we have A∩B∈λ(P)A \cap B \in \lambda (\mathcal{P})A∩B∈λ(P). Therefore ΠA⊇P\Pi_A \supseteq \mathcal{P}ΠA​⊇P.

□\square□

Unique Extension Theorem

Theorem. Let P\mathcal{P}P be a π\piπ-system. If ν1\nu_1ν1​ and ν2\nu_2ν2​ are measures (on σ\sigmaσ-fields F1\mathcal{F}_1F1​ and F2\mathcal{F}_2F2​) that agree on P\mathcal{P}P and there is a sequence An∈PA_n \in \mathcal{P}An​∈P with An↑ΩA_n \uparrow \OmegaAn​↑Ω and νi(An)<∞\nu_i (A_n) < \inftyνi​(An​)<∞ for i=1,2i = 1, 2i=1,2, then ν1\nu_1ν1​ and ν2\nu_2ν2​ agree on σ(P)\sigma( \mathcal{P} )σ(P).

Proof. Since νi\nu_iνi​ are measures on σ(P)\sigma(\mathcal{P} )σ(P), for all A∈σ(P)A \in \sigma(\mathcal{P})A∈σ(P),

νi(A)=lim⁡n→∞νi(A∩An). \nu_i (A) = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \nu_i (A \cap A_n). νi​(A)=n→∞lim​νi​(A∩An​).

It suffices to prove that ν1(A∩An)=ν2(A∩An)\nu_1 (A \cap A_n) = \nu_2 (A \cap A_n)ν1​(A∩An​)=ν2​(A∩An​) holds for all n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}^+n∈N+.

For a fixed nnn, now consider the set

L={B∈σ(P):ν1(B∩An)=ν2(B∩An)}⊆σ(P). \mathcal{L} = \{ B \in \sigma(\mathcal{P} ) : \nu_1 (B \cap A_n) = \nu_2 (B \cap A_n) \} \subseteq \sigma( \mathcal{P} ). L={B∈σ(P):ν1​(B∩An​)=ν2​(B∩An​)}⊆σ(P).

▹\triangleright▹ P⊆L:\mathcal{P} \subseteq \mathcal{L}:P⊆L: via assumption that P\mathcal{P}P is a π\piπ-system and that ν1\nu_1ν1​ and ν2\nu_2ν2​ agrees on P\mathcal{P}P.

▹\triangleright▹ L\mathcal{L}L is a λ\lambdaλ system:

  • Ω∈L\Omega \in \mathcal{L}Ω∈L.

  • If B∈LB \in \mathcal{L}B∈L, then Bˉ∈L\bar B \in \mathcal{L}Bˉ∈L since

    ν1(Bˉ∩An)=ν1(An)−ν1(B∩An)=ν2(An)−ν2(B∩An)=ν2(Bˉ∩An), \begin{aligned} \nu_1 ( \bar B \cap A_n) &= \nu_1 ( A_n ) - \nu_1 (B \cap A_n) \\ &= \nu_2 ( A_n ) - \nu_2 (B \cap A_n) = \nu_2 ( \bar B \cap A_n ), \end{aligned} ν1​(Bˉ∩An​)​=ν1​(An​)−ν1​(B∩An​)=ν2​(An​)−ν2​(B∩An​)=ν2​(Bˉ∩An​),​

    where the third equality follows from that ν1(An)=ν2(An)\nu_1 ( A_n ) = \nu_2 ( A_n )ν1​(An​)=ν2​(An​) and ν1(B∩An)=ν2(B∩An)\nu_1 (B \cap A_n) = \nu_2 (B \cap A_n)ν1​(B∩An​)=ν2​(B∩An​).

  • If BjB_jBj​ are disjoint sets in L\mathcal{L}L, then ∪j≥1Bj∈L\cup_{j \ge 1} B_j \in \mathcal{L}∪j≥1​Bj​∈L, since

    ν1((∪j≥1Bj)∩An)=∑jν1(Bj∩An)=∑jν2(Bj∩An)=ν2((∪j≥1Bj)∩An). \begin{aligned} \nu_1 \Big( \big( \cup_{j \ge 1} B_j \big) \cap A_n \Big) &= \sum_{j} \nu_1 (B_j \cap A_n) \\ &= \sum_{j} \nu_2 (B_j \cap A_n) = \nu_2 \Big( \big( \cup_{j \ge 1} B_j \big) \cap A_n \Big). \end{aligned} ν1​((∪j≥1​Bj​)∩An​)​=j∑​ν1​(Bj​∩An​)=j∑​ν2​(Bj​∩An​)=ν2​((∪j≥1​Bj​)∩An​).​

Using the π\piπ-λ\lambdaλ lemma, we get L⊇σ(P)\mathcal{L} \supseteq \sigma( \mathcal{P} )L⊇σ(P), which finishes the proof.

□\square□

Reference

[1]. R. Durrett, “Probability : theory and examples,” p. 432.
[2]. P. Billingsley, Probability and measure Anniversary Edition, 3rd ed. New York: Wiley, 1995.

Median-of-Mean

Posted on 2020-06-21

Suppose that we have an algorithm AAA that estimates the mean E[Y]E[Y]E[Y] of a random variable YYY within some specified range rrr with probability ρ>12\rho > \frac{1}{2}ρ>21​. We can derive a new algorithm A∗A^*A∗ from AAA that boosts the successful probability to 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ, as follows:

  1. Repeat AAA for m=12(ρ−0.5)2ln⁡1δm = \frac{1}{2 (\rho - 0.5)^2 } \ln \frac{1}{\delta}m=2(ρ−0.5)21​lnδ1​ times.
  2. Take the median of the mmm outputs.

To prove it, define the indicator random variable

Xi={1, if the i-th output of A is within the range r0,otherwiseX_i = \begin{cases} 1, \text{ if the } i \text{-th output of } A \text{ is within the range } r \\ 0, \text{otherwise} \end{cases} Xi​={1, if the i-th output of A is within the range r0,otherwise​

for 1≤i≤m1 \le i \le m1≤i≤m. Then E[Xi]=ρ>0.5E[X_i] = \rho > 0.5E[Xi​]=ρ>0.5.
Let μ=E[∑i=1mXi]=mρ\mu = E \left[\sum_{i = 1}^m X_i \right] = m\rhoμ=E[∑i=1m​Xi​]=mρ.

By Hoeffding’s inequality, for λ>0\lambda > 0 λ>0,

Pr⁡[∣∑i=1mXi−μ∣≥λ]≤exp⁡(−2λ2m)\Pr \left[ \left| \sum_{i = 1}^m X_i - \mu \right| \ge \lambda \right] \le \exp \left(- \frac{2\lambda^2}{m} \right) Pr[∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=1∑m​Xi​−μ∣∣∣∣∣∣​≥λ]≤exp(−m2λ2​)

Replacing λ\lambdaλ with μ−0.5m\mu - 0.5mμ−0.5m, and mmm with m=12(ρ−0.5)2ln⁡1δm = \frac{1}{2 (\rho - 0.5)^2 }\ln \frac{1}{\delta}m=2(ρ−0.5)21​lnδ1​, we get

Pr⁡[∑i=1mXi≤0.5m]≤Pr⁡[∣∑i=1mXi−μ∣≥m(ρ−0.5)]≤exp⁡(−2m(ρ−0.5)2)=δ\begin{aligned} \Pr \left[ \sum_{i = 1}^m X_i \le 0.5m \right] &\le \Pr \left[ \left| \sum_{i = 1}^m X_i - \mu \right| \ge m(\rho - 0.5) \right] \\ &\le \exp \left(- 2m(\rho - 0.5)^2 \right) \\ &= \delta \end{aligned} Pr[i=1∑m​Xi​≤0.5m]​≤Pr[∣∣∣∣∣∣​i=1∑m​Xi​−μ∣∣∣∣∣∣​≥m(ρ−0.5)]≤exp(−2m(ρ−0.5)2)=δ​

Note that if more than half of AAA outputs are correct, then the output of A∗A^*A∗ is correct. This happens with probability at least 1−δ1 - \delta1−δ.

Entropy and Message Transmission

Posted on 2020-06-18 Edited on 2020-06-30

We discuss another application that sheds light on meaning of entropy, the message transmission problem. In this model, a sender transmits a message to the receiver through a channel. In real world, the channel could be an optical fiber, a wireless channel, a hard disk etc. In the final application, the computer that writes and reads information from the hard disk is both the sender and the receiver.

In real world the channel is not perfect and the message transmitted is distorted by noise. It is natural to ask whether the message can be transmitted accurately under the noise, i.e., whether the receiver can recover the noisy message.

To study the problem, we need a mathematical model for both the channel and the noise. We focus on the simplest binary channel with bits of 0 and 1. The noise causes the bits to flip and is modelled by the distribution on the bit-flips. We study the simplest one that flips each bit independently with some identical probability p<0.5p < 0.5p<0.5. For a message with length nnn, the number of bit flips follows a Binomial distribution B(n,p)B(n, p)B(n,p). We call such channel a binary symmetric channel.

To protect the message against noise, a naïve way is to send the each bit multiple times. For example, if the sender wants to send a bit 1, it sends 101010 copies of 111 as 111111111111111111111111111111. The receiver decides that the bit sent is 1, if the majority of the 101010 bits it receives is 1.

Could it be improved? Repeating each bit may not be the mot efficient way against the noise. In general, if the sender wants to send a message of kkk bits, it can convert it into a new message of nnn bits and sends the new one. The receiver considers the nnn bits received as a whole, and try to recover the kkk-bit message the sender wants to send.

We call the method used by the sender to convert the original message the encoding function, and the one used by the receiver to recover the message the decoding function.

Definition. A (k,n)(k, n)(k,n) encoding function Enc:{0,1}k→{0,1}n\text{Enc}: \{0, 1\}^k \rightarrow \{0, 1\}^nEnc:{0,1}k→{0,1}n and a (k,n)(k, n)(k,n) decoding function Dec:{0,1}n→{0,1}k\text{Dec}: \{0, 1\}^n \rightarrow \{0, 1\}^kDec:{0,1}n→{0,1}k, where n≥kn \ge kn≥k.

Since the noise flips the bits randomly, it is impossible to have an encoding function and a decoding function without error (unless p=0p = 0p=0). Instead, we aim to control the probability of error within some specified threshold δ\deltaδ. To achieve this, we add redundancy to the message and encode a kkk-bit one into an nnn-bit one. Now, n−kn - kn−k is the amount of redundancy introduced. We would like to make n−kn - kn−k as small as possible. On the other hand, the value of n−kn-kn−k should positively related to ppp. The larger ppp is, the noisier the channel is and the larger n−kn - kn−k should be.

For fixed δ\deltaδ and ppp, the Shannon’s Theorem says that the smallest possible value of n−kn - kn−k we can achieve is roughly nH(p)n\mathbf{H}(p)nH(p). Intuitively, H(p)\mathbf{H}(p)H(p) is the amount of randomness the noise exerts on each bit. Therefore 1−H(p)1 - \mathbf{H}(p)1−H(p) is the maximum amount of information we can transmit by one bit.

Before we proceed, we prove the following lemma.

Lemma 1
For q∈R,q≤1/2q \in \mathbb{R}, q \le 1 / 2q∈R,q≤1/2 and n∈Nn \in \mathbb{N}n∈N, it hold that

∑i=0⌊qn⌋(ni)≤2nH(q)+log⁡n+12\begin{aligned} \sum_{i = 0}^{\lfloor q n \rfloor} \binom{n}{i} &\le 2^{ n \mathbf{H} ( q) + \log \frac{n + 1}{2} } \end{aligned} i=0∑⌊qn⌋​(in​)​≤2nH(q)+log2n+1​​

Proof.

∑i=0⌊qn⌋(ni)≤n+12(n⌊qn⌋)≤n+122nH(⌊qn⌋/n)≤2nH(q)+log⁡n+12\begin{aligned} \sum_{i = 0}^{\lfloor q n \rfloor} \binom{n}{i} &\le \frac{n + 1}{2} \binom{n }{\lfloor q n \rfloor } \\ &\le \frac{n + 1}{2} 2^{ n \mathbf{H} \left( { \lfloor q n \rfloor } / { n } \right) } \\ &\le 2^{ n \mathbf{H} ( q) + \log \frac{n + 1}{2} } \end{aligned} i=0∑⌊qn⌋​(in​)​≤2n+1​(⌊qn⌋n​)≤2n+1​2nH(⌊qn⌋/n)≤2nH(q)+log2n+1​​

The first inequality follows from that (ni)\binom{n}{i}(in​) is increasing for i≤n/2i \le n / 2i≤n/2 and that the summation is over at most (n+1)/2(n + 1) /2(n+1)/2 terms. The last one follows from that H(x)\mathbf{H}(x)H(x) is increasing for x≤1/2x \le 1 / 2x≤1/2 and that ⌊qn⌋/n≤qn/n=q<1/2{ \lfloor q n \rfloor } / { n } \le { q n } / { n } = q < 1/2⌊qn⌋/n≤qn/n=q<1/2.

■\blacksquare■

Shannon’s Theorem
Given a binary symmetric channel with flip probability p<1/2p < 1 / 2p<1/2 and for any any ϵ,δ>0\epsilon, \delta > 0ϵ,δ>0, when nnn is large enough,

  1. if k≤n(1−H(p)−ϵ)k \le n (1 - \mathbf{H}(p) - \epsilon)k≤n(1−H(p)−ϵ), there exist (k,n)(k, n)(k,n) encoding and decoding functions such that the receiver fails to obtain the correct message with probability at most 2δ2\delta2δ.
  2. ∄(k,n)\nexists (k, n)∄(k,n) encoding and decoding functions with k≥n(1−H(p)+ϵ)k \ge n (1 - \mathbf{H}(p) + \epsilon)k≥n(1−H(p)+ϵ) such that the decoding is correctly is at most δ\deltaδ for a kkk-bit input message chosen uniformly at random.

Proof of 1.

Intuition. When an nnn-bit message sss is transmitted through the channel, the number of flipped bits is roughly npnpnp. As p<1/2p < {1} / {2}p<1/2, we can find a λ>0\lambda > 0λ>0 such that p+λ<1/2p + \lambda < {1} / {2}p+λ<1/2. Let RRR be the received nnn-bit message and define d(s,R)d(s, R)d(s,R) the number of different bits between sss and RRR, i.e., the Hamming distance between sss and RRR. Given sss and ppp, let D(s,p)\mathfrak{D}(s, p)D(s,p) be the distribution of RRR on {0,1}n\{0, 1\}^n{0,1}n.

By Hoeffding’s inequality, it holds that

Pr⁡R∼D(s,p)[∣d(s,R)−pn∣≥λn]≤exp⁡(−2λ2n).\Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s, p) } [ |d(s, R) - pn | \ge \lambda n] \le \exp(- 2 \lambda^2 n). R∼D(s,p)Pr​[∣d(s,R)−pn∣≥λn]≤exp(−2λ2n).

Define the (p+λ)n(p + \lambda)n(p+λ)n ball centered sss as

Bs,(p+λ)n≐{r∈{0,1}n:d(s,r)<(p+λ)n}.B_{s, (p + \lambda)n} \doteq \{ r \in \{0, 1\}^n : d(s, r) < (p + \lambda)n \}. Bs,(p+λ)n​≐{r∈{0,1}n:d(s,r)<(p+λ)n}.

The the Hoeffding’s inequality implies that for large enough nnn, we have

Pr⁡R∼D(s,p)[R∉Bs,(p+λ)n]≤δ.\Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s, p) } [ R \notin B_{s, (p + \lambda)n}] \le \delta. R∼D(s,p)Pr​[R∈/Bs,(p+λ)n​]≤δ.

That is, with probability at most δ\deltaδ, the received message fall outside the ball Bs,(p+λ)nB_{s, (p + \lambda)n}Bs,(p+λ)n​. This motivates to decode each message in Bs,(p+λ)nB_{s, (p + \lambda)n}Bs,(p+λ)n​ as the original message the sender wants to send.

Further, by Lemma 1, the size of Bs,(p+λ)nB_{s, (p + \lambda) n}Bs,(p+λ)n​ is bounded by

∑i=0⌊(p+λ)n⌋(ni)≤2nH(p+λ)+log⁡n+12\begin{aligned} \sum_{i = 0}^{\lfloor (p + \lambda) n \rfloor} \binom{n}{i} &\le 2^{ n \mathbf{H} ( p + \lambda) + \log \frac{n + 1}{2} } \end{aligned} i=0∑⌊(p+λ)n⌋​(in​)​≤2nH(p+λ)+log2n+1​​

Therefore, the maximum number of non-overlapped balls we can pack into the message space {0,1}n\{0, 1\}^n{0,1}n is

2n2nH(p+λ)+log⁡n+12=2n(1−H(p+λ)−1nlog⁡n+12)\frac{2^n}{ 2^{ n \mathbf{H} ( p + \lambda) + \log \frac{n + 1}{2} } } = 2^{ n (1 - \mathbf{H} ( p + \lambda) - \frac{1}{n} \log \frac{n + 1}{2}) } 2nH(p+λ)+log2n+1​2n​=2n(1−H(p+λ)−n1​log2n+1​)

When nnn is large enough, this is at least 2n(1−H(p)−ϵ)2^{ n (1 - \mathbf{H} ( p ) - \epsilon) }2n(1−H(p)−ϵ).

Remark: Hoeffding’s inequality is an overkill. Chebyshev’s inequality suffices for this proof.

Designing Encoding and Decoding Functions.

This motivates one to design of encoding and decoding function as follows: find a set of messages s1,s2,...,s2k∈{0,1}ns_1, s_2, ..., s_{2^k} \in \{0, 1\}^ns1​,s2​,...,s2k​∈{0,1}n, such that

Bs1,(p+λ)n,Bs2,(p+λ)n,...,Bs2k,(p+λ)nB_{s_1, (p + \lambda)n}, B_{s_2, (p + \lambda)n}, ..., B_{s_{2^k} , (p + \lambda)n} Bs1​,(p+λ)n​,Bs2​,(p+λ)n​,...,Bs2k​,(p+λ)n​

are disjoint balls, and assign the messages in {0,1}k\{0, 1\}^k{0,1}k to the ones in {si}′s\{ s_i \}'s{si​}′s one by one. If the sending want to send iii, it sends sis_isi​. On receiving a message rrr, the receiver determines which ball rrr belongs to. The probability of decoding error is at most δ\deltaδ.

Question to ponder: can we find such a set efficiently, such that

Bs1,(p+λ)n,Bs2,(p+λ)n,...,Bs2k,(p+λ)nB_{s_1, (p + \lambda)n}, B_{s_2, (p + \lambda)n}, ..., B_{s_{2^k} , (p + \lambda)n} Bs1​,(p+λ)n​,Bs2​,(p+λ)n​,...,Bs2k​,(p+λ)n​

are disjoint?

Finding the Codewords.

It is left to find a set of satisfactory s1,s2,...,s2k∈{0,1}ns_1, s_2, ..., s_{2^k} \in \{0, 1\}^ns1​,s2​,...,s2k​∈{0,1}n. The method we show here does not find a set of non-overlapped balls. Instead it aims to find a set such that

if sis_isi​ is transmitted, then the probability received message rrr falls into the another ball, i.e., r∈Bsj,(p+λ)nr \in B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n}r∈Bsj​,(p+λ)n​ (j≠ij \neq ij=i), is less than δ\deltaδ.

The property implies that the overlap between Bsi,(p+λ)nB_{s_{i} , (p + \lambda)n}Bsi​,(p+λ)n​ and ∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)n\cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n}∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​ is less than δ\deltaδ (measured by probability). To formalize the statement, define the random variable SSS to be the message sent and RRR to be the one received. Given that S=siS = s_iS=si​ is sent, the conditional probability of receiving R=rR = rR=r is

Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R=r∣S=si]=pd(si,r)(1−p)1−d(si,r)\Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R = r \mid S = s_i] = p^{d(s_i,r)} (1 - p)^{1 - d(s_i, r)} R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R=r∣S=si​]=pd(si​,r)(1−p)1−d(si​,r)

To goal is to prove that it holds for all iii,

Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R∈∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)n∣S=si]=∑r∈∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)npr≤δ\Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R \in \cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n } \mid S = s_i] = \sum_{r \in \cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n} } p_r \le \delta R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R∈∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​∣S=si​]=r∈∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​∑​pr​≤δ

Then , by union bound, it holds that

Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R is not recovered correctly∣S=si]=Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R∉Bsi,(p+λ)n∨R∈∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)n∣S=si]≤Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R∉Bsi,(p+λ)n∣S=si]+Pr⁡[R∈∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)n∣S=si]≤2δ\begin{aligned} \Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [ R \text{ is not recovered correctly} \mid S = s_i] &= \Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [ R \notin B_{s_i, (p + \lambda)n} \vee R \in \cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n} \mid S = s_i] \\ &\le \Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [ R \notin B_{s_i, (p + \lambda)n} \mid S = s_i] + \Pr[ R \in \cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n} \mid S = s_i] \\ &\le 2 \delta \end{aligned} R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R is not recovered correctly∣S=si​]​=R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R∈/Bsi​,(p+λ)n​∨R∈∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​∣S=si​]≤R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R∈/Bsi​,(p+λ)n​∣S=si​]+Pr[R∈∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​∣S=si​]≤2δ​

That is, sis_isi​ is transmitted and decoded correctly with probability at least 1−2δ1 - 2 \delta1−2δ.

In what follows, we will prove the following claim:

Claim 1. If we generate 2k+12^{k + 1}2k+1 codewords uniformly at random from {0,1}n\{0, 1\}^n{0,1}n, then in expectation

Es1,s2,...,s2k+1∼U({0,1}n)[∑i=12k+1Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R∈∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)n∣S=si]]≤2kδ\underset{ {s_1, s_2, ...,s_{2^{k + 1} } \sim \mathbf{U}(\{0, 1\}^n) } } {\mathbb{E} } \left[ \sum_{i = 1}^{2^{k + 1} } \Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R \in \cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n } \mid S = s_i] \right] \le 2^k \delta s1​,s2​,...,s2k+1​∼U({0,1}n)E​⎣⎢⎡​i=1∑2k+1​R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R∈∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​∣S=si​]⎦⎥⎤​≤2kδ

Claim 1 implies that there exits a set of codewords s1,s2,...,s2k+1s_1, s_2, ..., s_{2^{k + 1} }s1​,s2​,...,s2k+1​ with

∑i=12k+1Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R∈∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)n∣S=si]≤2kδ\sum_{i = 1}^{2^{k + 1} } \Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R \in \cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n } \mid S = s_i] \le 2^k \delta i=1∑2k+1​R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R∈∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​∣S=si​]≤2kδ

If we send each sis_isi​ with probability 1/2k1 / 2^k1/2k, then the expected error probability is already δ\deltaδ. But we can have a stronger result: we can find a set of 2k2^k2k codewords, such that for each iii,

Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R∈∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)n∣S=si]≤2δ\Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R \in \cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n } \mid S = s_i] \le 2 \delta R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R∈∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​∣S=si​]≤2δ

W.L.O.G., suppose that s1,s2,...,s2ks_1, s_2, ..., s_{2^k}s1​,s2​,...,s2k​ are the ones with the smallest Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R∈∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)n∣S=si]\Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R \in \cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n } \mid S = s_i]PrR∼D(si​,p)​[R∈∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​∣S=si​] 's, it must be that

Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R∈∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)n∣S=si]≤2kδ2k=δ\Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R \in \cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n } \mid S = s_i] \le \frac{2^k \delta }{2^k } = \delta R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R∈∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​∣S=si​]≤2k2kδ​=δ

Proof of Claim 1. By Lemma 1, for a fixed rrr, the number of strings s∈{0,1}ns \in \{0, 1\}^ns∈{0,1}n such that d(s,r)<(p+λ)nd(s, r) < (p + \lambda) nd(s,r)<(p+λ)n is bounded by

∑k=0⌊(p+λ)n⌋(nk)≤n+122nH(p+λ)\begin{aligned} \sum_{k = 0}^{\lfloor (p + \lambda) n \rfloor} \binom{n}{k} &\le \frac{n + 1}{2} 2^{ n \mathbf{H} ( p + \lambda) } \end{aligned} k=0∑⌊(p+λ)n⌋​(kn​)​≤2n+1​2nH(p+λ)​

If a message sss is picked uniformly at random from {0,1}n\{0, 1\}^n{0,1}n, the probability such that

Pr⁡s∼U({0,1}n)[d(s,r)<(p+λ)n]≤n+12n+12nH(p+λ)\Pr_{s \sim \mathbf{U}(\{0, 1\}^n) } [d(s, r) < (p + \lambda) n ] \le \frac{n + 1}{2^{n + 1} } 2^{ n \mathbf{H} \left( p + \lambda \right) } s∼U({0,1}n)Pr​[d(s,r)<(p+λ)n]≤2n+1n+1​2nH(p+λ)

By union bound,

Pr⁡s1,s2,...,s2k+1∼U({0,1}n)[r∈∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)n]<2kn+12n+12nH(p+λ)=2k+log⁡(n+1)+nH(p+λ)−n−1\begin{aligned} \Pr_{s_1, s_2, ...,s_{2^{k + 1} } \sim \mathbf{U}(\{0, 1\}^n) } [ r \in \cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n} ] &< 2^k \frac{n + 1}{2^{n + 1} } 2^{ n \mathbf{H}( p + \lambda) } \\ &= 2^{ k + \log (n + 1) + n \mathbf{H} ( p + \lambda) - n - 1 } \end{aligned} s1​,s2​,...,s2k+1​∼U({0,1}n)Pr​[r∈∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​]​<2k2n+1n+1​2nH(p+λ)=2k+log(n+1)+nH(p+λ)−n−1​

As k≤n(1−H(p)−ϵ)k \le n(1 - \mathbf{H}(p) - \epsilon)k≤n(1−H(p)−ϵ), when nnn is sufficient large, it follows

Pr⁡s1,s2,...,s2k+1∼U({0,1}n)[r∈∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)n]<2log⁡n+12+n(H(p+λ)−H(p)−δ)≤δ2\begin{aligned} \Pr_{s_1, s_2, ...,s_{2^{k + 1} } \sim \mathbf{U}(\{0, 1\}^n) } [ r \in \cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n} ] < 2^{ \log \frac{n + 1}{2} + n ( \mathbf{H} ( p + \lambda) - \mathbf{H} ( p) - \delta) } \le \frac{\delta}{2} \end{aligned} s1​,s2​,...,s2k+1​∼U({0,1}n)Pr​[r∈∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​]<2log2n+1​+n(H(p+λ)−H(p)−δ)≤2δ​​

Therefore,

Es1,s2,...,s2k+1∼U({0,1}n)[Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R∈∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)n∣S=si]]=∑r∈{0,1}nPr⁡s1,s2,...,s2k+1∼U({0,1}n)[r∈∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)n]⋅Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R=r∣S=si]≤δ2\begin{aligned} &\underset{ {s_1, s_2, ...,s_{2^{k + 1} } \sim \mathbf{U}(\{0, 1\}^n) } } {\mathbb{E} } \left[ \Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R \in \cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n } \mid S = s_i] \right] \\ &= \sum_{r \in \{0, 1\}^n } \Pr_{s_1, s_2, ...,s_{2^{k + 1} } \sim \mathbf{U}(\{0, 1\}^n) } [ r \in \cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n} ] \cdot \Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [ R = r \mid S = s_i] \\ &\le \frac{\delta}{2} \end{aligned} ​s1​,s2​,...,s2k+1​∼U({0,1}n)E​[R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R∈∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​∣S=si​]]=r∈{0,1}n∑​s1​,s2​,...,s2k+1​∼U({0,1}n)Pr​[r∈∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​]⋅R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R=r∣S=si​]≤2δ​​

and

Es1,s2,...,s2k+1∼U({0,1}n)[∑i=12k+1Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R∈∪j≠iBsj,(p+λ)n∣S=si]]≤2k+1δ2=2kδ\underset{ {s_1, s_2, ...,s_{2^{k + 1} } \sim \mathbf{U}(\{0, 1\}^n) } } {\mathbb{E} } \left[ \sum_{i = 1}^{2^{k + 1} } \Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R \in \cup_{j \neq i} B_{s_{j} , (p + \lambda)n } \mid S = s_i] \right] \le 2^{k + 1} \frac{\delta}{2} = 2^k \delta s1​,s2​,...,s2k+1​∼U({0,1}n)E​⎣⎢⎡​i=1∑2k+1​R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R∈∪j=i​Bsj​,(p+λ)n​∣S=si​]⎦⎥⎤​≤2k+12δ​=2kδ

■\blacksquare■

Proof of 2.

The difficulty here is to prove that the claim holds for arbitrary (k,n)(k, n)(k,n) encoding and decoding functions. The proof relies on an important property:

the decoding function Dec\text{Dec}Dec is a function on {0,1}n\{0, 1\}^n{0,1}n

For any r∈{0,1}nr \in \{0, 1\}^nr∈{0,1}n, there is a unique output Dec(r)∈{0,1}k\text{Dec}(r) \in \{0, 1\}^kDec(r)∈{0,1}k. The decoding function needs to decide the unique message {0,1}n\{0, 1\}^n{0,1}n the sender want to send.

Now, define

Si≐{r∈{0,1}n:r is decoded correctly if si is sent}S_i \doteq \{ r \in \{0, 1\}^n : r \text{ is decoded correctly if } s_i \text{ is sent} \} Si​≐{r∈{0,1}n:r is decoded correctly if si​ is sent}

The SiS_iSi​’s are non-overlapped and we have,

∪i=12kSi⊂{0,1}n\cup_{i = 1}^{2^k} S_i \subset \{0, 1 \}^n ∪i=12k​Si​⊂{0,1}n

If sis_isi​ is sent, then by Hoeffding inequality, with probability at least 1−exp⁡(−2λ2n)1 - \exp(- 2\lambda^2 n)1−exp(−2λ2n), the received message RRR is likely to fall into a ring centered at sis_isi​:

ring(si)≐{r∈{0,1}n:∣d(r,si)−pn∣<λn}\text{ring} (s_i) \doteq \{ r \in \{0, 1\}^n : |d(r, s_i) - pn |< \lambda n \} ring(si​)≐{r∈{0,1}n:∣d(r,si​)−pn∣<λn}

Finally, if the messages s1,s2,...,s2ks_1, s_2, ..., s_{2^k}s1​,s2​,...,s2k​ are sent uniformly at random, i.e., i∼U[1,2k]i \sim \mathbf{U}[1, 2^k]i∼U[1,2k], then

Pr⁡[R is decoded correctly]=∑i=12k∑r∈SiPr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R=r∣S=si]Pr⁡i∼U[1,2k][S=si]=12k∑i=12k∑r∈SiPr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R=r∣S=si]\begin{aligned} \Pr[ R \text{ is decoded correctly}] &= \sum_{i = 1}^{2^k} \sum_{r \in S_i } \Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R = r \mid S = s_i] \Pr_{i \sim \mathbf{U}[1, 2^k]} [ S = s_i] \\ &= \frac{1}{2^k} \sum_{i = 1}^{2^k} \sum_{r \in S_i } \Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R = r \mid S = s_i] \end{aligned} Pr[R is decoded correctly]​=i=1∑2k​r∈Si​∑​R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R=r∣S=si​]i∼U[1,2k]Pr​[S=si​]=2k1​i=1∑2k​r∈Si​∑​R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R=r∣S=si​]​

Observed that Si⊂ring(si)∪(Si∩ring(si))S_i \subset \text{ring} (s_i) \cup (S_i \cap \text{ring} (s_i) )Si​⊂ring(si​)∪(Si​∩ring(si​)), we get

Pr⁡[R is decoded correctly]≤12k∑i=12k(∑r∉ring(si)Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R=r∣S=si]+∑r∈Si∩ring(si)Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R=r∣S=si])≤12k∑i=12k(exp⁡(−2λ2n)+∑r∈Si∩ring(si)Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R=r∣S=si])\begin{aligned} &\Pr[ R \text{ is decoded correctly}] \\ &\le \frac{1}{2^k} \sum_{i = 1}^{2^k} \left( \sum_{r \notin \text{ring} (s_i) } \Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R = r \mid S = s_i] +\sum_{r \in S_i \cap \text{ring} (s_i) } \Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R = r \mid S = s_i] \right) \\ &\le \frac{1}{2^k} \sum_{i = 1}^{2^k} \left( \exp( -2\lambda^2n) +\sum_{r \in S_i \cap \text{ring} (s_i) } \Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R = r \mid S = s_i] \right) \end{aligned} ​Pr[R is decoded correctly]≤2k1​i=1∑2k​⎝⎛​r∈/ring(si​)∑​R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R=r∣S=si​]+r∈Si​∩ring(si​)∑​R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R=r∣S=si​]⎠⎞​≤2k1​i=1∑2k​⎝⎛​exp(−2λ2n)+r∈Si​∩ring(si​)∑​R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R=r∣S=si​]⎠⎞​​

Note that for r∈Si∩ring(si)r \in S_i \cap \text{ring} (s_i)r∈Si​∩ring(si​), as p<1/2p < 1 / 2p<1/2, it holds that

Pr⁡R∼D(si,p)[R=r∣S=si]≤p⌈(p−λ)n⌉(1−p)n−⌈(p−λ)n⌉\Pr_{R \sim \mathfrak{D}(s_i, p) } [R = r \mid S = s_i] \le p^{ \lceil(p - \lambda) n \rceil} (1 - p)^{ n - \lceil(p - \lambda) n \rceil } R∼D(si​,p)Pr​[R=r∣S=si​]≤p⌈(p−λ)n⌉(1−p)n−⌈(p−λ)n⌉

We obtain

Pr⁡[R is decoded correctly]≤exp⁡(−2λ2n)+12k∑i=12k∑r∈Si∩ring(si)p⌈(p−λ)n⌉(1−p)n−⌈(p−λ)n⌉≤exp⁡(−2λ2n)+12k∑i=12k∑r∈Si∩ring(si)p(p−λ)n(1−p)n−(p−λ)n=exp⁡(−2λ2n)+p(p−λ)n(1−p)n−(p−λ)n∑i=12k∑r∈Si∩ring(si)12k=exp⁡(−2λ2n)+ppn(1−p)n−pn(1−pp)λn2n−k=exp⁡(−2λ2n)+2n−k−nH(p)(1−pp)λn\begin{aligned} &\Pr[ R \text{ is decoded correctly}] \\ &\le \exp( -2\lambda^2n) + \frac{1}{2^k} \sum_{i = 1}^{2^k} \sum_{r \in S_i \cap \text{ring} (s_i) } p^{ \lceil(p - \lambda) n \rceil} (1 - p)^{ n - \lceil(p - \lambda) n \rceil } \\ &\le \exp( -2\lambda^2n) + \frac{1}{2^k} \sum_{i = 1}^{2^k} \sum_{r \in S_i \cap \text{ring} (s_i) } p^{ (p - \lambda) n } (1 - p)^{ n - (p - \lambda) n } \\ &= \exp( -2\lambda^2n) + p^{ (p - \lambda) n } (1 - p)^{ n - (p - \lambda) n } \sum_{i = 1}^{2^k} \sum_{r \in S_i \cap \text{ring} (s_i) } \frac{1}{2^k} \\ &= \exp( -2\lambda^2n) + p^{ pn } (1 - p)^{ n - pn } \left(\frac{ 1 - p}{ p} \right)^{\lambda n} 2^{n - k}\\ &= \exp( -2\lambda^2n) + 2^{n - k - n \mathbf{H}(p)} \left(\frac{ 1 - p}{ p} \right)^{\lambda n} \end{aligned} ​Pr[R is decoded correctly]≤exp(−2λ2n)+2k1​i=1∑2k​r∈Si​∩ring(si​)∑​p⌈(p−λ)n⌉(1−p)n−⌈(p−λ)n⌉≤exp(−2λ2n)+2k1​i=1∑2k​r∈Si​∩ring(si​)∑​p(p−λ)n(1−p)n−(p−λ)n=exp(−2λ2n)+p(p−λ)n(1−p)n−(p−λ)ni=1∑2k​r∈Si​∩ring(si​)∑​2k1​=exp(−2λ2n)+ppn(1−p)n−pn(p1−p​)λn2n−k=exp(−2λ2n)+2n−k−nH(p)(p1−p​)λn​

Conditioning on that k≥n(1−H(p)+δ)k \ge n (1 - \mathbf{H}(p) + \delta)k≥n(1−H(p)+δ),

Pr⁡[R is decoded correctly]≤exp⁡(−2λ2n)+2−n(δ+λlog⁡1−pp)\Pr[ R \text{ is decoded correctly}] \le \exp( -2\lambda^2n) + 2^{- n (\delta + \lambda \log \frac{ 1 - p}{ p} ) } Pr[R is decoded correctly]≤exp(−2λ2n)+2−n(δ+λlogp1−p​)

By choosing sufficient small λ\lambdaλ and large enough nnn, Pr⁡[R is decoded correctly]\Pr[ R \text{ is decoded correctly}]Pr[R is decoded correctly] can be arbitrary small.

■\blacksquare■
